org.openadaptor.core.adaptor
Class Adaptor

java.lang.Object
  org.openadaptor.util.Application
      org.openadaptor.core.adaptor.Adaptor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Administrable, IComponent, ILifecycleComponentManager, ILifecycleListener, IMessageProcessor, IRegistrationCallbackListener, java.lang.Runnable
public class Adaptor
extends Application
implements IMessageProcessor, ILifecycleComponentManager, java.lang.Runnable, Administrable, ILifecycleListener

An Adaptor is a core framework class that serves as the "top level" Runnable bean. This bean is responsible for managing the lifecycle of ILifecycleComponents and one or more IRunnables. If any of the IRunnable components implement the ITransactionInitiator interface then the Adaptor will call their TransactionManager setter. Once running it receives data from the IRunnables that it manages and delegates these to another IMessageProcessor, typically this delegate is a Router.
An Adaptor implements Runnable and will return when all the IRunnable components it manages have exited. If an IRunnable exits with an non-zero return code, it will stop any other IRunnable components.
When an Adaptor is configured with an IMessageProcessor that is also an ILifecycleComponentContainer it will register itself as the ILifecycleComponentManager. Routers and Pipelines implement the ILifecycleComponentContainer interface. This avoids having to duplicate the configuration for all of the components that are referred to in the Router / Pipeline in the Adaptor. The majority of all the openadaptor examples are within the context of an Adaptor. Either as code which create and runs an Adaptor or as a spring configuration which via the SpringApplication class is run as a stand alone process.

Author:
perryj

setRunInCallingThread

public void setRunInCallingThread(boolean runRunnablesInCallingThread)
Parameters:
runRunnablesInCallingThread - if true and there is only one IRunnable then the adaptor will not create and run another thread when run() is called

setTransactionManager

public void setTransactionManager(ITransactionManager transactionManager)
Parameters:
transactionManager - ITransactionManager to use, defaults to TransactionManager. Any components that implement ITransactionInitiator will have their setter called with this when the adaptor is started.

setRunConfiguration

public void setRunConfiguration(AdaptorRunConfiguration config)
Allows a run configuration to define restart strategies and scheduling.

register

public void register(ILifecycleComponent component)
Registers a an ILifecycleComponent to be managed once the adaptor is started. Throws a runtime exception if the adaptor state is not State.STOPPED. Typically this is called by a ILifecycleComponentContainer as a result of the adaptor calling ILifecycleComponentContainer.setComponentManager(ILifecycleComponentManager)

Specified by:
register in interface ILifecycleComponentManager

unregister

public ILifecycleComponent unregister(ILifecycleComponent component)
Throws a runtime exception if the adaptor state is not State.STOPPED.

Specified by:

getExitCode

public int getExitCode()

getExitErrors

public java.util.List getExitErrors()
Returns a list of exit errors (instances of Throwable) from all Runnables in this adaptor. The list will be empty if none of the nodes (connectors, processors) in the adaptor produced an error, or if the adaptor has an exception handler set up (via the exceptionProcessor property on the Router).

Returns:
a list of exit errors from all Runnables in the adaptor. Empty list if no unhandled errors occured in any of the runnables.

public java.lang.String getState()
Returns the state of this adaptor. Method primarily for JMX use.

Returns:
the state of the adaptor as a String
